awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Preparing Urban Milwaukee for Pathways in Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Wisconsin faces increasingly inequitable access to Computer Science (CS) content in schools. Affluent suburban schools add courses, such as CS Principles (CSP), at a record rate. Schools with fewer resources have little or no CS offerings and see meager access diminished as scarce while CS teachers are lured away to industry and the suburbs. Marquette University and The Learning Partnership have already made significant inroads in expanding Wisconsin's CS professional development opportunities for teachers. Prior work over the last five years has provided CS Professional Development to over 1,850 K-5 teachers, reaching over 67,000 school children. Careful assessment will allow the team to explore deeper questions about how prior CS exposure effects students later in the CS pathway, why execution of CS initiatives are so unevenly effective in different parts of the city, and how to strengthen and expand a pathway in a dynamic urban school system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: American Institutes for Research in the Behavioral Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit 

Computer science (CS) is a young discipline relative to other STEM fields, and K-12 CS remains poorly defined and unevenly executed. The American Institutes for Research’s (AIR’s) work on this collaborative grant measured systems change efforts in an urban school district to improve CS education while evaluating and building the capacity of a researcher-practitioner partnership (RPP) to strengthen and expand a computer science pathway in a dynamic urban school system. 

 

Broader Impacts

The RPP’s previous five years of efforts introduced CS courses in more than 200 middle and high schools across urban, suburban and rural parts of the state, created alternative licensure pathways for existing in-service teachers, and piloted a novel CS teaching methods course has been piloted. In this project, the RPP worked to put new CS content in the path of all 76,000+ school children in an urban school district. The RPP emphasized inquiry-based instruction with student-relevant content designed to naturally flow into other STEM courses that struggle for rigor, relevancy and relationships.

 

Outcomes

Systems change. AIR surveyed teachers and principals across the district to measure changes in perceptions over time. Across the lifetime of the RPP, a greater percentage of teachers who completed the survey reported: (a) their professional development emphasized computational thinking integration, inquiry-based activities, and monitoring students’ understanding of computational thinking; (b) integrating computational thinking their math classes; and (c) the use of inquiry methods increased, whereas the use of whole-class discussion decreased.​ A greater percentage of principals reported: (a) satisfaction with their teachers’ ability to teach computational thinking skills​; (b) teachers taking a positive attitude towards students’ computational thinking abilities​; and (c) teachers having professional development opportunities to teach computational thinking.

RPP evaluation. AIR regularly administered a survey with a three-point scale (early or in development phase, middle phase, on-track toward maturing phase). The survey was adapted from Penuel and Gallagher’s Are We a Partnership Yet? diagnostic rubric to measure five dimensions of an effective RPP (Henrick, Cobb, Penuel, Jackson, & Clark, 2017). AIR also interviewed the RPP members to identify strengths and challenges aligned to the five dimensions. Across the grant period, the RPP members consistently rated these dimensions of the RPP as on-track toward maturing: building trust and cultivating partnership relationships; supporting the partner practice organization in achieving its goals; and building the capacity of participating researchers, practitioners, practice organizations, and research organizations to engage in partnership work. Over the course of the RPP, the members reported that these two dimensions improved from the early or in development phase to on-track toward maturing phase: ability to conduct rigorous research to inform action and producing knowledge that can inform educational improvement efforts more broadly.

From the RPP members’ perspectives, the factors contributing to the growth along two of the dimensions and the consistent on-track toward maturing ratings for the other three dimensions included: regular meetings with consistent attendance; centrally located and organized meeting agendas and notes; the diversity of the RPP members’ perspectives; researchers learning to avoid the use of jargon; streamlined systems for collecting, organizing, analyzing, and synthesizing data; the adoption and consistent use of a collaborative data discussion protocol; the creation of a data summary table to distill findings for different audiences; and user-friendly data visualizations.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2024
Modified by: Carrie Scholz
